Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemistry and Biochemistry Summer Undergraduate Research Experience at Kennesaw State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professors Mitchell, Linenberger, and colleagues of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Kennesaw State University (KSU) reach out to 2-year and smaller 4-year partner institutions to recruit undergraduate students from institutions that typically do not have the resources to provide a research experience to their chemistry or biochemistry students. The targeted institutions also enroll a diverse population of students. The student researchers work in the lab one-on-one with faculty research mentors and other students on projects designed to be accessible to the undergraduates. The broader impact of the project is to expose a diverse pool of talented students, who have had limited exposure to scientific research, to the excitement of how science is done - working on projects that contribute to the understanding of important problems. All of the students are encouraged to consider a career in science. Society benefits from citizens who are more aware of the process of science and the benefits of scientific research.

The summer research experience at KSU offers the undergraduate research participants (URPs) the opportunity to participate in research that encompasses a broad range of study in chemistry including biochemistry, analytical chemistry, chemical education, inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, organic chemistry, organometallic chemistry, and physical chemistry. The URPs participate in weekly group meetings with their research mentor and his/her other research students, in workshops on topics ranging from laboratory safety to career opportunities. They also participate in an end-of-the-summer research symposium and in social activities designed to help them assimilate into their research groups. They form an initial network of colleagues and scientific associates that can help them in their future careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to recruit students at smaller academic institutions in the Southeastern United States who were not likely to have access to significant research opportunities or even be aware that such opportunities existed and provide them with such access. An additional goal was to specifically provide undergraduate research opportunities for students from underserved populations. As a result, these students would be retained as a chemistry or biochemistry major and potentially move on to a graduate program in the disciplines ultimately increasing the diversity of those working in chemistry and biochemistry.

We identified several institutions as partner institutions from which we would specifically recruit students: Dalton State College, Georgia Perimeter College, Middle Georgia State University, Albany State University, Clayton State University, Fort Valley State University, Georgia Highlands College, University of West Georgia, and Columbus State University. We made every effort to visit each of these schools at least once during the recruiting period for the grant to meet with faculty and students about the research opportunities of the program and to recruit students. As an aside, some of the partner institutions have research opportunities for students, but the breadth of opportunities was limited at the time of the grant. Also, Georgia Perimeter College became part of Georgia State University during the period of the grant, but our earlier contacts with that institution led us to accept students from Perimeter College of Georgia State University. With our program as part of the database of Research Experiences for Undergraduates the number of applicants increased and became more diverse from across the United States. With these recruitment efforts, 25 students from various institutions from across the Southeastern United States participated in the Kennesaw State University Chemistry and Biochemistry Undergraduate Research Experience across the 3 offerings of the program. Of the 25 student participants, 14 came from the partner institutions. In terms of ethnicity, 56% identified as female and 56% identified as being part of a historically underrepresented ethnic group in STEM.

As part of the program, each of the student participants was paired with a research mentor with whom they worked for the 9-week period of the grant each summer. Throughout the summer the students participated in an introduction to research workshop focused on developing key skills such as literature searches, using Microsoft Excel, statistical analysis, and the development and presentation of scientific research. There were additional professional development opportunities which included a resume and LinkedIn workshop, a “Careers in Chemistry” panel discussion and tours of the local chemical industry. Additional excursions were also planned for the students to build relationships with one another including bowling, attending an outdoor concert, and an Atlanta Braves baseball game. At the end of the summer experience, each student presented the results of their research at a mini-symposium, that also included  summer undergraduate research students who were not part of the NSF-sponsored program but who did participate in some of the summer activities. Students were encouraged to further their research experience past the 9-weeks by presenting their work at a regional or national meeting, funding for which was provided as part of the grant support. In total, 10 students were able to present their work for a total of 14 different regional or national meeting presentations. Additionally, the work of the CBSURE students has led to 2 published papers with student authorship. 

Evaluation of the program using the Undergraduate Research Self-Assessment instrument was favorable regarding the students’ experience and the impact of the program on their views of research, and their future plans. Regardless of the year of implementation, students identified as having gained in all areas of thinking and working like a scientist and research work. There was greater variability in their perceived gains in specific research skills due to the wide range of research experiences offered to the students. Of the 25 students that participated in the program, all have either graduated in a STEM field or are currently completing their degree in a STEM field. Several students had to take time off to explore potential career paths but ultimately came back to a STEM field and have returned to school to complete their undergraduate degree. Of those who have graduated and with whom we are still in contact, most have either moved on to a graduate program in STEM (e.g. PhD Chemistry, PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, or MPH) or are currently working in a STEM related field (e.g. pharmacy technician, lab technician, or medical assistant). Overall, the program provided the students an opportunity to explore different avenues within Chemistry and Biochemistry and as a result helped facilitate the ultimate retention of these students in a STEM degree program.
